reviews.review:
Really good game. Surpasses the previous 2 BioShock games in all ways.

Graphics are really good compared to the 2 past games.
Sounds are good.
Music is good and quite appropriate for the era the game is set in.

Story is really good. Ending was not entirely surprising to me, as a few key moments in the story hinted at what was to come.

Gameplay is great and allows for numerous tactics and styles to fit in with how someone would play.

For anyone playing on a modern system, make sure you cap your frames per second to 60 or even 59, set vsync on and compatibility mode for Windows 7. This game glitches out badly with the UI in the game if frames exceed 60. You can't pick up objects, search containers or even quit the game once the bug hits and need to alt-tab out the game and restart the PC. It sometimes happens even with the above mentioned preventative measures, but much more rarely, but that is a minor nuisance to play this great game!

A game almost any FPS enthusiast would enjoy!

good shoot game, bad bioshock game.
e l i z a b e t h

This game amazed me during the gameplay, with fun fights that ended up well and easy and with good graphics for the time this game was made, The plot twist had me thinking a lot and got me really confused, Although the game system was sometimes disappoiting, with vigors that shouldn't even be vigors and the lockpick system, compared with the 2 previous games, it's a bit garbage. But in overrall I give this game a 8/10, since it's a game that I wanted to play since I was around 10 years old or slightly odler than that and gives me enough nostalgia from my good times as a younger kid.

-Very good narrative
There is always a man, a city... There is a flying city , Colombia, this time with racist, zealotus people worshiping government figures led by a prophet. Workers have no rights and civil war is near. There are no little sisters but one girl to save. It is literally an alternate opposite reality to Rapture. I don't know if the story is better than the first game but it is clearly more interesting with more cinematic moments. Elizabeth might be the first game character to tag along with you without being annoying. I really like Luteces.
-Good production
Game takes place in 1912 (mostly) with advanced tech. Music, people, environments are done really well, again. Colombia is a sight to see. Booker and Elizabeth are voiced pretty well.
-Okay gameplay
Gameplay is mostly same with much more verticality. There are also little side missions. Weapon, vigor and equipment upgrades are more basic. I used handcannon and RPG most of the time.

It is definetely a game everyone should experience. Story, characters and environments are it's most powerful aspects even though it's a shooter.

Burial in the Sea:
First DLC is basicly fan service for Rapture but a good one. Second DLC actually changes gameplay and makes it a stealth game which is refreshing. It also connects stories of Colombia and Rapture.

Confesso que no inicio nÃ£o tava dando muito valor pra esse jogo mas depois de um tempo a historia foi cada vez ficando mais interessante, e chega nesse final maravilhoso minha nossa,caralho mas que final.
Es un gran juego porque es muy buena la jugabilidad y aun mejor la historia en especial por el plot twist

El juego sera muy bello y tendra un cambio bastante importante de sus antecesores, pero termina siendo tedioso.

Lo recomiendo porque me gusto mucho mas la sensacion de disparo, el equilibrio entre las armas y los tÃ³nicos, todo eso mejoro mucho de los anteriores.

Pero es el peor en cuanto a rendimiendo y bugs. Ami me deberia sobrar para jugarlo y aÃºn asÃ­ consume una cantidad estupida de GPU, a pesar de superar los 150 fps, a veces tengo tirones raros y el peor de todos es cuando hay mini cinematicas de abrir puertas o tocar botones, sin ningun motivo se traba y si no lo destrabas a tiempo se bugea absolutamente todo el juego, es un asco absoluto.

Lei que muchos tiene Bug Stuck en diferentes puntos del juego, ami me ocurre en las cinematicas estas, mas que nada llegando al final del juego, es constante en los ultimos episodios, tuve que rejugar uno 4 veces hasta lograr avanzar. A esta altura del partido deberia estar patcheado.

Loved it. Works as a stand alone game.

8 years later still a massive let down of what could have been. Shooting is solid but lacks a lof of the choice and interactivity that the original game had. Story is "im 14 and this is deep" bait. 

Levels feel like levels, not actual real lived in spaces like in Biochock 1's rapture. They have a "museum" feel to them and there is very limited interaction in them. The art direction and design is top notch though.

Shooting has been improved at the expense of depth/choice and utility in the plasmids. Now each "vigor" is just another way to deal damage, rather than a way to exploit a weakness of an enemy. Enemy variety is pretty lacking with most enemies being grunt soldiers, in which the game throws 8-10 of them to you at a time. Kill all of them, walk to the next "arena" rinse and repeat. There are no more tense moments of encountering splicers fighting big daddies or splicers surprising you. Its the same formula repeated throughout. 

Won't get into the story, the ending is convoluted and you will need to look up what actually happened. Many people consider this "deep" and therefore praise the game for it. The characters are forgettable unlike Andrew Ryan and CM Porter in B1 and Minerva's Den. 

The 2011 E3 demo set the hype too high. I hope they deliver a bioshock game in the next one instead of a standard 2 gun FPS with bioshock elements.
ta piola, tan piola que lo compre xd

Bisohock Infinite was the most ambitious title in the series, and the most disappointing. I can't recommend you avoid it enough. 

The gameplay is complete phoned in Call of Duty wannabe nonsense, and the plot is a tangled cringefest. The mental gymnastics from fans trying to piece this mess together, and connect it to the original, honestly contributed to me giving up on games ever achieving art-status. 

Watch one of the hundreds of reviews or analyses if you are genuinely interested in it thematically. Otherwise pass.

Whatever this is, it isn't Bioshock.
It has barely any relation to the Shock genre of games.

Looking at the game on it's own, without relating it the previous Bioshock/System Shock games, it's mediocre.  The only positives I can credit it for are it's setting, soundtrack and voice performance.  If you do decide you want to try it, get it at it's cheapest possible price.

The gameplay is dull and un-engaging.  The story is abysmal and nonsensical. 

Ken Levine is a hack.

I played last night for the 1st time in more than 4 yrs, & was floored.  Yes, it looks good, but my god, the atmospheric audio is the best in the biz, & I'm a pro audio engineer, so my ear knows.  There's so much love & detail put into the game, that it oozes out of  your monitor. It's no secret that the game's staggeringly beautiful, so much so, that it can hold it's own, w/many games released today.  If you're considering a replay or finally purchasing it, just do it. 

This was technically my first game as an adult.  When I was 13, I played Super Metroid religiously, but then I got into girls & that was the end of that.  As a musician/composer, I didn't have the time for gaming, then later as an engineer, impossible, but then I got old, & was prescribed gaming therapy for some neuro issues I struggle with, & Bioshock Infinite was the 1st game I HAD to play. With all the hype,& in particular, the ad campaign, & w/all the buzz from the community, I had to find out what it was all about.  A couple months later, I'd find one of the only other games that has ever captured my devotion entirely (I guess I'm really picky?), & that's the infamous Fortnite, which I still play today, (I can see some artistic influences) & I'm one of only a handful of 40yr + players to ever qualify for FNCS finals. I've  grinded only a few games over the past 4 years & it's helped manage my neurological problems to a near miraculous degree, when nothing else did.  I was the worst. I was new to everything, from game mechanics, to KB/M, & it took me a year to become "decent".  

Point being; when I came back to Bioshock Infinite, on just medium difficulty, I got into some sticky situations a few times, because the game is legit challenging.  I can head-shot nearly everything that pops up (Thank you Kovaak), but the NPC's are pretty smart & quick.  They come from all sides, so no camping, & I actually died a couple times :steammocking: after deciding I could play thru w/o a death lmao.  I have no shame admitting that.  What did really surprise me, was my last save from playing it in 2017; surprisingly only 20hrs play-time, after I really struggled with the game as a noob?  I didn't realize or understand that guns could be upgraded.  Or that all the clothes were "armor", that I was supposed to wear & that could also be upgraded.  It all makes me wonder how in the F, I actually completed the game?  I know it's probably a 6-8 hr avg play-thru, but I can't over-state how bad I was, & how little I knew take advantage of.  That's the past tho, & thanks in part to this amazing game, my short-term amnesia treatment has been greatly improved, & that feels like a real miracle, even tho it took years of losing PvP matches in other games to get to where I am today.  It all started with Bioshock Infinite.  So Go Play the Game!

Bioshock Infinite suffers from all of the issues of its predecessors with some new issues thrown in.

== Old Problems ==
For context, I don't believe Bioshock 1 or 2 to be particularly good First Person Shooters.  While 2 was certainly better than 1 in that regard (particularly through the addition of dual wielding), neither has the kind of enemy design or level design to be especially worth playing over other single player FPS games without the benefit of RPG systems to become stronger or the story to keep the player motivated.
Infinite suffers from poor enemy design and poor level design even more than its contemporaries.  The levels often boil down into fairly basic rooms that are locked until you dispatch all the enemies in them, with little in the way of interesting elevation or terrain features (including skyhook) to take advantage of.  The enemies are, themselves, fairly braindead and even those with unique powers like the Fireman or Handymen don't have expanded AI as much as they have larger pools of health and new toys to hit you with that don't differ so radically from guns and skyhooks of normal enemies.
But, Infinite now introduces some new and original issues as well, problems one would assume that anyone making an RPG or FPS wouldn't make in the year 2013.
== Progression and Death ==
In Bioshock Infinite, you get stronger via upgrading your guns and getting new gear.  You upgrade your weapons by purchasing upgrades for them with money.  However, money is also the main resource you lose when you die.  The practical upshot of this is that if you enter a certain encounter that is giving you problems due to your weapons being too weak and not having enough ammo, then you'll most certainly end up actually getting weaker by the end of it because you'll lose your 'experience' needed to make your weapons stronger.
In Bioshock 1 and 2, weapon upgrades were handled via dedicated, single-use upgrade booths rather than by the same resource you lost when you died.  This meant that when you died, you lose your chance to get more Health and Adam boosting items, but you weren't set back in your progression.  You lost time and convenience, not progress.
This issue is compounded by the fact that in Bioshock Infinite, in an attempt to present itself as a more serious FPS, the player is limited to carrying only two weapons at a time.  This, on it's own, is not an issue.  However, the ammo drops in each combat space are specific to the enemies' weapons you encounter in that space.  In other words, if you've got a pistol and a shotgun but all the enemies are using machine guns, then you're not likely to run into a lot of pistol or shotgun ammo.  This means you have to make a frustrating choice between keeping the weapons you've bothered upgrading or getting a weapon that has ammo available for it in your current area.  And that new weapon you pick up has to be upgraded separately of the other weapons as well.
== Plot and Politics ==
The biggest issue with Bioshock Infinite though, by far, is that the plot is a major step back from that of its predecessors, both in its characters and its overarching events.  Bioshock 1 and 2 explored opposite sides of extreme economic theories falling apart in practice due to their incompatibility with contradictions in human behavior.  The failings of Andrew Ryan and Sofia Lamb is the overly simple model of human beings they construct in their heads to make their economic beliefs hold true.
Bioshock Infinite, by contrast, attempts to do the same with partisan political beliefs but ends up comparing apples to oranges.  It initially presents a society ingrained with abusive and bigoted beliefs, both in its citizenry and its laws, as the form of extremism for one side of the political aisle.  However, it chooses to compare that form of mundane horror to a more rare but shocking one in the form of a socialist/communist revolution gone out of control.  This centrism compares what was to what might be but only explores each at their most shallow level, and explores the contrast between these potentials even less.
Ideally, the equivalent of Columbia for the Vox Populi would look something like a Stalinist Authoritarian regime, the kind that would come to sweep Russia and China in the 40s.
The choice to present the Vox Populi's extremism as an extravagant version of the Storming of the Bastille rather than the Reign of Terror might indicate how little thought was given to the text of the subject matter the writers were tackling.
This is wrapped up in the quantum mechanics plot point, wherein the idea of 'multiple possible worlds' is presented but used only to suggest that "dude, anything could happen" without properly tying the idea back to the core "themes" of almost nihilistic moral relativism presented in the previous political comparison.
